text.0: i will declare the manly deeds of indra the first that he achieved the thunderwielder.
text.1: he slew the dragon then disclosed the waters and cleft the channels of the mountain torrents.
text.2: he slew the dragon lying on the mountain his heavenly bolt of thunder tvaṣṭar fashioned.
text.3: like lowing kine in rapid flow descending the waters glided downward to the ocean.
text.4: impetuous as a bull he chose the soma and in three sacred beakers drank the juices.
text.5: maghavan grasped the thunder for his weapon and smote to death this firstborn of the dragons.
text.6: when indra thou hadst slain the dragons firstborn and overcome the charms of the enchanters.
text.7: then giving life to sun and dawn and heaven thou foundest not one foe to stand against thee.
text.8: indra with his own great and deadly thunder smote into pieces vṛtra worst of vṛtras.
text.9: as trunks of trees what time the axe hath felled them low on the earth so lies the prostrate dragon.
text.10: he like a mad weak warrior challenged indra the great impetuous manyslaying hero.
text.11: he brooking not the clashing of the weapons crushedindras foethe shattered forts in falling.
text.12: footless and handless still he challenged indra who smote him with his bolt between the shoulders.
text.13: emasculate yet claiming manly vigour thus vṛtra lay with scattered limbs dissevered.
text.14: there as he lies like a bankbursting river the waters taking courage flow above him.
text.15: the dragon lies beneath the feet of torrents which vṛtra with his greatness had encompassed.
text.16: then humbled was the strength of vṛtras mother indra hath cast his deadly bolt against her.
text.17: the mother was above the son was under and like a cow beside her calf lay danu.
text.18: rolled in the midst of neverceasing currents flowing without a rest for ever onward.
text.19: the waters bear off vṛtras nameless body the foe of indra sank to during darkness.
text.20: guarded by ahi stood the thralls of dāsas the waters stayed like kine held by the robber.
text.21: but he when he had smitten vṛtra opened the cave wherein the floods had been imprisoned.
text.22: a horses tail wast thou when he o indra smote on thy bolt thou god without a second.
text.23: thou hast won back the kine hast won the soma thou hast let loose to flow the seven rivers.
text.24: nothing availed him lightning nothing thunder hailstorm or mist which had spread around him.
text.25: when indra and the dragon strove in battle maghavan gained the victory for ever.
text.26: whom sawest thou to avenge the dragon indra that fear possessed thy heart when thou hadst slain him.
text.27: that like a hawk affrighted through the regions thou crossedst nineandninety flowing rivers.
text.28: indra is king of all that moves and moves not of creatures tame and horned the thunderwielder.
text.29: over all living men he rules as sovran containing all as spokes within the felly.
